metadata.title: Python For Data Science — A Guide to Data Visualization with Plotly | by Nicholas Leong | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Python For Data Science — A Guide to Data Visualization with Plotly
metadata.description: A Beginners Guide to Data Visualization and Exploration with Plotly. Full Code Run Through for Pie and Bar Charts, Scatter Plots, Bubble Plots and many more!

all_paragraphs: Greetings my fellow data practitioners, welcome back to your weekly read on another episode of my data journey. This week we will be talking about data visualizations, how important are they and the python library you should be using to make them. So hop on, relax and enjoy the ride.

If you are a data practitioner like myself, you would’ve been through situations where you need to explain your data to someone else. You need to tell a story, get your point across and convince maybe your colleague, supervisor or even your CEO. Now, imagine you’re trying to explain that less than 20% of male survived the Titanic Dataset. What would it look like ?
As you can see, visualizations play a huge part in explaining your data. Showing numbers on a screen doesn’t really apply to some people out there. Visuals do make a difference.

Visualizations assist the data scientist in understanding and discovering hidden stories in their data. A simple histogram can tell you more in an instance than you trying to figure out the distribution by yourself. Here’s a distribution of the fares in the Titanic Dataset.
Plotting this out straight up tells us that majority of our customer’s fares range under the 100 dollar mark. This is good information, but it doesn’t tell us the whole story.
Visualization gives you answers to questions you didn’t know you had. — Ben Schneiderman

When data visualization first became a thing, data practitioners were plotting graphs as they were exploring their data with Pandas. The library that made this possible was called Matplotlib, it was a good library because it is :
However, people who have used it long enough felt that it was dull. Even the official functionality of Matplotlib states that :
Matplotlib is mainly deployed for basic plotting. — Matplotlib

Hence, data practitioners who wanted a more interesting library that consist of more plotting patterns, options and an easier syntax flocked to the Seaborn Library. At the time, Seaborn was the go to for many people. Here’s a Seaborn plot for the histogram we had just plotted.

The Seaborn Library also provides insane amount of plots ranging from Hexbin Plots to Violin Plots, the kind of plots you never thought you needed. Here’s a brief preview of the kind of plots they offer.

However, there was still a problem. All of these libraries offer static plots. These plots can only tell you what they show on screen. You aren’t able to dive deeper into the plots, hover over points to find out information or add filters.
Plots that are able to perform functions like these are named Interactive Visualizations.

Interactive Visualizations are popular for adding a ton of information on top of the plots you’re presenting, unlocking possibilities and making you look 10x cooler. It’s hard to put in words, let’s visualize what I’m trying to tell you.Here’s the same distribution plot for the fares in the Titanic Dataset once again.

Notice how we can hover over the histogram and know what distribution (male or female) we are referring to, know the values we are hovering over, zoom in and out to dive deeper into the values and filter for the male or female gender. You can already imagine how powerful this is and how this will contribute to your story telling in data.
The library that made this possible is called Plotly.
Plotly is the Python Library for interactive data visualizations. Plotly allows you to plot superior interactive graphs than either Matplotlib or Seaborn.
We will be working a lot with Pandas in this guide. Hence, a solid understanding on the basics of Pandas is required.Here’s an article I wrote on Pandas to get you up to speed.
Regardless of all the benefits Plotly brings, people tend to avoid it due to:
Don’t be afraid, I will hold your hand through these tough times. Grab a cup of coffee, sit in a comfortable position and prepare to do some code.
We will be working with Jupyter Notebook in this guide.Let’s get this one right.

Due to how Plotly operates, it saves your plot into a separate html file and opens it in a different window directly. This will happen when you run the code in the console/terminal. Hence, we use plotly.offline, iplot and init_notebook mode to help us plot the graphs on Jupyter Notebook itself.

In this guide, I’m going to focus on the original plotly syntax because it provides maximum customization on your graph. Plotly Express and Cufflinks provide a better alternative for easy code plotting, but they don’t offer many tools as the original syntax do.
Before plotting anything, you need to know what you are trying to plot. Ask yourself questions like:
After answering some of these questions, you can start to plan out your plot.
We will be using the classic titanic dataset, continuing our data exploration from the Pandas Guide I wrote.
Again, the main objective of this dataset is to study what are the factors that affect the survivability of a person onboard the titanic.
First thing that comes to my mind is to display how many passengers survived the titanic crash. Hence, visualizing the Survived column itself will be a good start.

In Plotly, we define Graph Objects to be plotted. The 3 main parameters required for a plot are the Data, Layout and Figure parameters. Hence, we need to define them in a clear and concise way where someone else will be able to understand what we are trying to plot.
Since we are plotting the Survived column alone, our data will be a

Plotly’s Pie chart takes in required parameters which are labels and values by default. Hence, we define the labels as the unique values of the Survived column, which in this case are the values 1 and 0. The values we are trying to display are the count of these unique values. We then define our data as a list containing the Pie Chart object we had just defined.

LayoutThe layout means quite literally what it means, the layout of your plot. In here, you can define plot titles, x and y axis titles, show legends, activate filters/sliders and many more customization to your chart. Since we are only plotting a Pie Chart for a single column, let’s not make it too fancy.
We are creating a layout object containing only the title parameter here.
FigureFigure is what you are trying to plot, it takes in the data and layout parameter by default which we had already defined.
We can then display this plot by literally plotting it with Plotly.

Voila, you had successfully plotted an interactive plot. Notice how we are able to see the actual values while hovering over each section. This is extremely useful when presenting visualizations in a clean and professional manner. Try plotting a Pie Chart for the Sex and Pclass columns as well.
Next, let’s explore some of the numerical columns which are the Age and the Fare columns. When plotting numerical columns alone, we think of a distribution plot. In this case, I will use a histogram.
Perfect. We can clearly see how the age of passengers is distributed here. Note that we can tweak 2 useful parameters for Histograms which are:
Cool. So far, we had only plotted graphs with one variable. Let’s now study the relationship between those variables by plotting them against each other.
Let’s find out the relationship between our Age and Fare columns. This would be useful to answer questions like — does older people tend to buy more expensive fare tickets ?
When plotting 2 numerical values against each other, a Scatter plot will be a good place to start.

Note that I added some subtle features in this plot which are the x and y axis titles as well as the value to be displayed when hovering over the point. You can customize the display value by changing the text parameter in the code.

Observing the plot, we don’t really see a linear relationship between the columns. The Fares tend to hit a price ceiling below 300. We also observe that older people buy cheap fares as well. Besides that, we can’t really tell much simply relying on this plot alone.

We can further investigate this by looking at the Pclass column which is the ticket class for the passengers. By plotting the average age and fare for each Pclass, we can see if there’s something to connect here.

Let’s plot a Bar Chart showing these information. For each Pclass, we want to display the average age and fare in that Pclass. If you notice, we are starting to deal with multiple variables here, 3 to be exact.

For simplicity’s sake, I will plot the Pclass on the x-axis, average age on the y-axis and the average fare as a color scale in our bar chart. Hence, we will need to compute the average age and fare for each Pclass first.
After that, we can plot our graph.
We added two new parameters here which are the:

Cool. By hovering over the bars, we can see the average Age and Fare for each Pclass, not to mention the clear colour scale defining the fares. The bar chart clearly shows that the age and fares decreases as Pclass increases.

We can also confirm this by plotting the distribution of the age and fare for each Pclass. This will give us the clear picture of the data for each Pclass instead of the Average. We shall use distplot for this.
Distribution Plots are like histograms, but they include another count plot on the bottom to better display the distribution.We have to import an extra library for distribution plots.
Let’s plot 2 graphs, the distribution for age and fares according to their Pclass separately.

Both distribution plots clearly shows that the lower Pclasscorrelates to a higher age and higher fare. In a layman’s term, it means that the first class tickets cost more, and older people tend to purchase first class tickets.

After concluding that, we want to know how does the survivability relate to these variables. We can plot the survivability against them with the bubble plot. Bubble plots allow visualization up to 4 variables which can help us communicate our point here.
Bubble Plots are similar to scatter plots, but they have an additional size parameter that defines the radius for each dot.
From the Bubble Plot, we can see that:
Here’s the full code for all the visualizations in this article.

You have just learnt most of the basic charts from Plotly by running through this data exploration session with me. Isn’t it amazing what you can conclude just by relying on the basic charts. By now, you should realize how powerful Plotly visualizations are in exploring and understanding your data.

We are not done yet with our data exploration and visualization with this dataset. I am working on more advanced plotly visualization write-ups like adding sliders/filters and more, you can absolutely expect more posts like this. In the meantime, feel free to check out my other articles to temporary fill your hunger for data.
To end, I always drop a quote.
Its 2020, stop using Matplotlib and Seaborn, level up your visualizations.
You can also support me by signing up for a medium membership through my link. You will be able to read an unlimited amount of stories from me and other incredible writers!

I am working on more stories, writings, and guides in the data industry. You can absolutely expect more posts like this. In the meantime, feel free to check out my other articles to temporarily fill your hunger for data.
Thanks for reading! If you want to get in touch with me, feel free to reach me at nickmydata@gmail.com or my LinkedIn Profile. You can also view the code for previous write-ups in my Github.
Data Scientist turned Engineer — Crunching data and writing about it so you don’t get headaches. https://www.linkedin.com/in/nickefy/
